text:
Good afternoon, and welcome
to our fifth session-- what becomes of the global
economy, and globalization,

featuring Professor Dani Rodrik
of the Harvard Kennedy School. Our moderator is HBS professor
and senior associate dean

Debora Spar. Please note that a
recording of this session will be made available to
a broader public audience.

If during Q&A, you're called
on to pose a question, your name and voice will
be part of that recording.

When we get to
Q&A, we'll ask you to signify an interest in asking
a question by using the raise

hand function. We're also going to
invite you to use the chat function to either have another
mechanism for asking a question

or for reacting to the
conversation that's unfolding. Handing it over to you, Deb.

Great. Thank you so much. It's a great pleasure to
be here this afternoon, and particularly to welcome
Dani Rodrik, albeit virtually,

to the Harvard Business School. Dani, as you heard, is one
of the leading economists of globalization writing today.

He and I first crossed
paths many, many years ago, when I was a graduate student,
and he was a young professor.

And we shared a mentor in
the person of Ray Vernon, who

was one of the great scholars
of both Harvard Kennedy School and Harvard Business School, and
really one of the first people

to study globalization
as a phenomenon. And Dani has gone on very much
to follow in Ray's footsteps,

and to become one of the
most insightful scholars and critique people who
are willing to critique

the global economy. Dani's work has been
both controversial and wildly heralded,
and so it's a pleasure

to bring him here today. So Dani, let me start
by setting the stage. A lot of your work is deeply
rooted not only in economics,

but in economic history. Unlike many other
economists, you tend to see economic
developments as embedded in

and affected by the context
in which they occur. So what is your sense, at this
admittedly very early moment,

of how the coronavirus
will eventually play out? Is the virus going to
push the global economy

to a major inflection
point, or do you believe that we will,
after some period of time,

pretty much return
to business as usual? Thank you, Debora.

It's good to see you and to
join, virtually, this session.

I'm very happy you brought
up Ray Vernon's name. Ray is not only the person
who put us in touch,

but he's also the
person who first made me cross the river, to
spend time at the business

school when he was
on the faculty. And I was one of his
undergraduate research

assistants. Ray-- and Ray's work, of course,
is terribly relevant to all

these discussions. Probably his best book
is this book called

"Sovereignty At Bay--"
I would read that-- and that was published in 1971. And it was right.

It was about globalization. And I think you can read that
book and many of those insights

are still extremely relevant. So that's the kind of-- I think an apt
introduction, also,

to the question you're
asking, is that globalization has a history.

And it goes all the way
back to, I think, not

just the late 19th century
with gold standard, but, you know, even beyond that. You can go through history
and study, in fact--

you know, we're talking
today about how coronavirus is the product of globalization,
and how it has made

countries more interdependent. But of course, you
know, the Black Death was also the plague
that came from Asia

and traveled through the
trade routes to Europe. It took a little bit
longer than it takes today,

but it's still very much
the same kind of phenomenon. So I think one very
important thing

that I've learned about
looking at globalization from a historical angle is
that there is not such--

there's not just
one globalization. There are very many
different globalizations,

and they don't fall into
our laps from the sky. We actually design
those globalizations.

Every global economic system
relies on certain rules

that are either written down-- for example, today,
they're written down in trade agreements with
the WTO, or these articles

of agreement of
the IMF, in Europe, it's Acquis communautaire,
paper with nearly 200,000 pages

of regulations. So it's all written down
and we make choices. Or sometimes, it's rules
that are internalized

in the behavior of
policymakers, because they say, this is what responsible
policymakers do.

This is how they act. And they internalize
certain ways of behaving that's consistent
with that particular model

of globalization. I think the kind
of globalization

that we moved into
sometime into the 1990s

is a model that I've
called hyperglobalization. And I gave it a name-- I thought that we needed
to give it a name,

because I thought it
was very different from the globalization that we
had before 1990, a system that

was associated with the
Bretton Woods Agreement, sometimes called the Bretton
Woods-GATT regime, but roughly

between the end of the Second
World War through the 1980s. And the '80s were a
period of transition.

I think the hyperglobalization
was very different from the
pre-hyperglobalization period.

Sorry, Dani, to interrupt-- I'm just getting a note that
your voice is a little bit quiet, so if you could just
make it a little louder,

that'd be great. Thanks. I can try. And I can also try to speak
a little bit closer to the--
That sounds good. OK. Thanks. And I think the--

hyperglobalization, I think, was
distinguished from the earlier

stage of globalization in a
number of critical respects. I think it went much deeper
in terms of its ambitions,

in terms of how closely to
entangle different countries'

economies together. And so we moved to
what economists often call a model of
deep integration,

from shallow integration. So we had much more
expansive trade agreements that dealt not only with
import tariffs, or quotas

at the border, but
also health systems, or with public regulations, with
intellectual property rights,

with investment tools. Trade agreements became much
more invasive, in a way.

And also, we moved,
critically, into an area where financial globalization,
the free flow of finance,

became a norm rather
than the exception. It was a critical difference.

And I think the
total effect of these was to put it to caricature
somewhat, but not--

I think it's still meaningful. Then, we moved to a
kind of globalization where national
economies were supposed

to function in the service
of the world economy, rather than the other way
around, rather than the world

economy being in the service
of national economies. Of course, there were
lots of beneficiaries of this system-- large
corporations, big bank,
big pharma benefited. But it created a lot of strains.

And these strains were
already resulting in a kind of fraying of the system.

So without question, in
this moment of crisis, we are seeing very big
decline in world trade.

Without question, the
decline in world trade and cross-border financial
flows will be much bigger

than the decline in
world output and GDP. But I think that's--

the weakening of the underlying
set of rules and practices

really pre-date the coronavirus. And we see it in a number
of different dimensions.

We see that global value
chains already weren't expanding nearly as rapidly.

Actually, cross-border
finance never really recovered from the 2008-9 crisis.

And we see it, of course,
in the political backlash. And trade tensions have
risen significantly

between US and China, but
also globally more so. So already, there were
things that were already

happening that
made it quite clear that we were on an
unsustainable course. And it wasn't quite clear
what's going to happen.

So I don't see as much
an inflection point as a kind of a reinforcement,
once we are out of this crisis,

a reinforcement of
these existing trends. So I want to come back
to sort of these trends,

but before I do that, I
want to turn something a little bit different.

But some of your work
has also addressed issues of economic
inequality, both inequality

between countries and economic
inequality within countries,

sometimes exacerbated by
this hyperglobalization that you were just describing.

So once again, do you think
that this current moment is going to exacerbate the divide
between the rich and the poor?

Or is it perhaps
some kind of a wake up call about the extent to
which the elites of the world--

and I think you and I would both
count ourselves among those-- are deeply dependent on
the low wage workers who

are providing the
food, and the delivery, and all these other things
that have, until now, been

kind of invisible within
the global system. Well, I think, you know--

I think most elites had heard
the wake up call-- again, once again, before the crisis.

I mean, I don't need to
tell you or your students about sort of the
kind of soul searching

that's been taking place
among corporate elites in terms of thinking
about corporate social

responsibility, the economic
and social governance rules,

and how to be more responsible
and responsive citizens. And I think that shows,
that corporations realized

that there was something
that they needed to be in the absence of
sufficiently active government

response. So I think-- you know, I
fault my side of the river for essentially having
thrown the problem

on the laps of
corporations, and saying that you deal with this,
because we are unable to come up with tax regimes, or
regulations, or labor

markets, that are producing
the kinds of desirable, more inclusive economic
arrangements--

so you corporations,
you deal with it. And so that's-- definitely,
it was already happening.

I think you
mentioned inequality. I think the fundamental
issue, as I see it right now,

is less inequality, per
se, than the disappearance

of good and secure jobs. So it's much more a
problem of the middle--

the middle classes and
the lower middle classes-- than the problem
of the very bottom.

Now, it's absolutely true
that in the United States, it's both. In the United States, it's both
a squeezing of the middle class

and a great increase in
inequality since the 1980s. But if you look at Europe-- I mean, take a
country like France,

where we've had some
of the yellow vests,

and the rise of the National
Front, the authoritarian right.

You know, inequality really
hasn't increased significantly in France, certainly not
compared to the United States.

But what has increased is a
sense of economic insecurity, that good jobs are
becoming scarcer,

and that there's a much
bigger gap between the middle

and the elites. Society is being divided, not
just economically, but also

socially, culturally,
cognitively, between a set of elites
that are perfectly comfortable in a global world,
whose services are in demand,

whose networks are
global, who have the assets and the
knowledge to prosper

with these new technologies
and this new global economy, and middle classes
that are increasingly

feeling bound to their
local communities, don't have the
same opportunities.

And that feeling that-- you know, elites are basically
simply telling them that, look, you have to get on with it.

Just learn to live with it. Get trained, get the skills. And that's, I think, where a lot
of the backlash is coming from.

And then the crisis, again,
makes this so obvious, I mean,

between those of us
who are beneficiaries of this technology, and can
keep on doing what we're

doing over Zoom, and service
workers, who don't necessarily

have this kind of ability. So it's just building
into this divide. So there's a big alignment
between the existing cleavage

that predates the
coronavirus, and the deepening of these divisions through
the crisis at the same time.

Now, the big question is,
you know, that's where it is. So what comes out of this? And it's not entirely clear.

Yes, there is a reckoning. Yes, there is an understanding. But we can come out
of this in two ways.

One is to say, look, we really
need major structural changes in what we're doing.

The other way is to say,
to point to the populists, to the authoritarian
right, and say, see,

if you don't listen to
us, that's what you get. So we have to return to
the status quo, ante. Unfortunately, there
has been too much

of that second kind of response
on the part of the elites. And that's where I
think we're going wrong.

OK, so I may want to
come back to part of that if we have time here. But in general, my plan is to
ask one more set of questions.

And then, at around 2:40,
we will open the floor, such as it, to questions.

So folks listening, if you want
to get your questions ready, that should be in about
nine or 10 minutes from now.

And we ask you, please,
that you raise your hands if you have something
you'd like to ask Dani.

So let me turn to the
policy side of this. And I think many
of us recently have

been recalling the famous
advice that Rahm Emanuel gave to Barack Obama back
in 2008, at the height

of the last financial crisis,
reminding him never to let a good crisis go to waste.

Should we now, in this moment
when everybody's watching, and everybody's worried,
and everybody's turning

to government, or any kind
of authority looking for help and change, are there policies
that we in the United States,

or we in Massachusetts,
or governments in any other country
around the world, should be putting in place?

Is this the time now to
do things differently? And one in particular that
I'd love your thoughts on

is the idea of the universal
basic income, which seems to have gotten a fair
amount of traction, not least

because Andrew Yang has
somewhat surprisingly thrown his weight behind it and
gotten a lot of interest.

So are there things we
can do in the next six months, a year, to actually
try and effect change?

I think there are
several aspects of this. One is, does this
crisis contribute

to an overall changing
of the narrative, and the need to move into
more structural changes

in their policies? And therefore, you
have bigger support, greater political support,
for more radical changes.

So that-- whether it's health
policy, or labor market policies, or
corporate governance,

or industrial relations. We're willing to move
in to the wealth tax.

We're willing to move
into areas that have

that we've stayed away from. The second is that you
have to also bear in mind

that many of the things-- that is a crisis that
requires very urgent response.

So you need to take care of
people who are being laid off. You have to address the issues,
the income support issues,

of a very large number of people
that are finding themselves in very destitute situations.

So take your example of
universal basic income. I'm not a big UBI fan,
for reasons I'll tell you.

But right now, I'd be
in favor of providing

the most immediate sort of
income support to people

that one can do. So at this point,
UBI seems something that we should be in favor of.

Now, the reason that I don't
think UBI is the solution is UBI is a kind of a way
of resigning ourselves

to the inevitability of this
situation, which is really

what's poisoning our economies,
our societies, our politics, which is the absence
of secure, good jobs.

And so the UBI is the answer
to saying, well, you know, technology gives
us this problem.

And you know, we can't
deal with it any other way. And let's just
give people money. I think people--

I mean, again, I'll do amateur
psychology and sociology. I think people want to lead
meaningful lives, which may not

mean your regular eight
hour a day, 40 hours a week,

kind of a job. I think we can
envisage flexibility. But our sense of
identity, who we

are, how we're
contributing to society, is partly determined by the
kind of jobs that we have. So I think we all
are societies--

passively generate the kind
of meaningful, secure jobs

that people want to have. And that means
that's where I think our interventions have to be.

It's not to give people
money, or to redistribute after the fact. It is to engage in the kinds
of industrial policies,

productivist policies,
industrial relations, labor market interventions,
competition policies,

innovation policies, even. Because the direction
of technology-- it, again, doesn't fall
onto our lap from the sky.

You know, we decide which
direction of technology that we're actually
incentivizing.

Just like we can have
more green technologies by subsidizing certain
types of innovations,

we can have more labor
friendly technologies by subsidizing or
redirecting technology

in a particular kind of a way. But that kind of calculus still
has not entered our thinking,

either at the federal level, in
terms of our federal innovation systems, or at the
level of corporations,

in terms of innovation,
technology policy. And people think employment,
or the good jobs,

is going to be somebody
else's problem. And if not, we can always
provide them with UBI anyhow.

But I think that's really where
the big structural changes will have to be-- to think about what
kind of industrial policies,

what kind of innovation policies
can we think of, that are much more employment friendly,
that deal with--

the technology comes in
the service of society, in service of workers,
rather than telling workers

that you have to be in
the service of technology. And to love and-- Let me jump in there. And again, I'm sorry.

I'm getting folks saying
they can't hear us very well. So I will try and scream. And maybe you can. And if there's anything the
tech folks can do on the volume,

that would be great. But let me just throw that
one quick prod, if you will.

Can we-- we, writ large-- really do anything to stop
the march of technology?

You know, the jobs that you
talk about, many of them, they are going away.

And my fear is that
one of the effects of this coronavirus
pandemic is that we

will hasten the march towards
replacing humans with machines.

We're all getting used to
replacing human interaction in only a month, with Zoom.

So is it even realistic to
talk about trying to bring back those jobs, given
what history tells us

about the march of
technology, which is that it's really, really hard to reverse.

So I'm not talking
about reversing the march of technology. I'm not a Luddite in--

I didn't say you were. --any sense of the word. But I'm just saying
that we do know

that the direction of
technology is not-- it's something that's
partly under our control.

So if-- let's say if our
federal technology policies are

in the hands of the Defense
Advanced Research Projects Agency, DARPA.

So they're going to be thinking,
what kind of new technologies we will need? Oh, you know, we
actually want to reduce

battlefield casualties. So let's try to encourage
automated vehicles.

And that's great from
a defense standpoint, but it's not
necessarily so great

from an employment standpoint. But that's not what
they think about. So you can imagine--
there's all kinds of ways

in which our existing policies--
you know, we tax employment, but we subsidize
capital equipment.

So it's no wonder
that firms are going to invest, and from a social
standpoint, overinvest,

in automation and robots. But historically,
I think the way

that we've dealt with
the problem of labor replacing technology
is that we've also,

as technologies
increase, we've also increased the range of tasks
that medium skilled people

can do. So this is one of the major ways
you can balance the employment. And so we can envisage
putting much more effort

into creating
technologies that's going to increase
the kind of tasks

that relatively less skilled,
or middle skilled people, do. So in varying practical terms,
that might mean sort of--

you know, AI
technologies, for example, that enable nurses to do
physicians' work, or less

trained teachers to do more
skilled teachers' work. So you know, you and
I can be replaced

by people who don't
necessarily have our education.

But the institutional and
legal and tax environment

shapes whether we're making
those decisions or not. So one reason that, in the
medical context, that nurses

can't do what physicians can
do, is partly because physicians prevent nurses from doing that,
because they have the power.

And they can decide--
you know, we're the club-- we decide
what a physician can do. So there are all kinds of legal
and institutional conditions

that determine which type
of technologies can develop. What I'm suggesting is
that these are things

that we can partly control. And we understand
that our challenge

is in terms of creating
more inclusive societies, is going to be to
create technologies

that are going to be more
friendly to the middle class, that will need to
also incorporate that calculus in
our decisions when

we think about our
innovation policies and the institutional setting
in which that takes place.

OK, that's fabulous. So why don't we turn now to
questions from the audience?

So I'm going to give the
controls back to Andy to call on folks.

And again, people, please
feel free to put your hands up if you have a question for Dani.
Thanks, Deb. Ariel, please. Ariel Yoffie, please unmute.
Hello. Oh, sorry. I didn't mean to raise my hand.

But I guess one of my
questions would be, how do you look at the
introduction of technology

and the long term impacts
and implications on privacy, and what that might
do to Deb's point--

our economy and
increasing inequality.

Thank you, Ariel,
for the question. This might push me way
beyond my area of expertise.

Privacy is, I think we recognize
what the trade offs are there.

And I think, especially
after the present crisis, it's going to be really
important to chart

an appropriate path
between information systems that are able to help us, track
and trace infected individuals,

while also allowing
for the right to privacy and without violating
anybody's human rights.

I really don't have
anything fundamental to say on those issues.

But on inequality
per se, I think I would just repeat what I
just said in the last round

with Deb, about the
need for us to think about technology as something--

just like globalization,
as something that just doesn't come
to us, ready made.

That this is-- you know, we
have a lot of agency in the way that we form it.

But that's going to require
action on a number of different levels, both at
the federal level,

the state and local level,
and also in terms of the kinds

of values that I think
corporate leaders are going
to internalize when they're--

in the way that they think
about deploying technology. One other thing I would
say, in relation to that,

is that we know that
when workers have greater voice in the enterprise,
that actually

makes a difference to the
type of technologies that are adopted, and for
the way in which they're adopted, in the way
that they're deployed.

So I think one of the
changes that we actually need to consider
also is workers'

voice in the enterprise. I think that's, besides
beside addressing directly

the questions about
inequality, inclusion also is, I think, has a useful
indirect effect, because

of the influence that has on
the manner in which technology gets adopted and deployed.
Adi Raghunathan, please.
Please unmute.
Adi? OK, let's go to Nick Picca.
Nick, please unmute.
Let's try Rob Solomon, please. Can you hear me?

Yes. Go ahead. Yes, so I guess I'm
wondering, aside

from simply slowing the pace
of adoption of automation

or other similar
technologies, can you offer specific policies
that, in your mind,

would address some
of the problems with technology adoption
that you have very

helpfully illustrated? Well, I think with respect
to technology, it's--

there are both correcting some
of the things that are wrong,

as well as you doing additional
things that we're not doing. So in the first
category, I would

say that the existing
structure of R&D

and tax incentives
that are embedded in our national
economic policies

need to be reconsidered. I mean, again, our existing
policies effectively

amount to subsidizing
automation and taxing the use of employment.

That's because of
various incentives to capital depreciation
and so forth,

that sort of capital investment
and physical investment incentives, as well as
many R&D incentives.

And then, our
policy is of taxing labor, because of various
charges on employment,

and the way that we run our
health system and so forth. So that's sort of
one layer of policy--

sort of national or
federal level policies that would go in the
direction of reducing

the relative taxation of
labor compared to capital. You could even envisage
going completely

in the other
direction, by coming up with policies that are
actually subsidizing the use of employment-friendly
technology.

So for example, it's
now well understood that we need to subsidize
green technologies.

That's what's done at the
federal level, through ARPA-E. But there are also other tax and
subsidies put in place as well.

Why not apply the same
principle to technologies that actually provide
precisely the kind of labor

augmentation-- that is, give
relatively less skilled workers the kinds of skills with which
they can do the jobs of more

educated workers. And thirdly, I would say
that, I think, probably

at the most local
level, I think we need state and local
authorities, local development

agencies, working with firms,
and domestic-- and medium

sized firms, or larger
investors in their localities, working with them in a
kind of iterative fashion

to help them think about the
consequences of different types of technology adoption.

And working with
community colleges, working with local community
groups, and local investors

to get the firms and those who
are making choices with regard to technology adoption
to internalize some

of the social costs of not
generating enough jobs, or not generating good jobs.

So there are these
different layers of policies I think that
need to be in place.

I've written about this
in a couple of places. I'm happy to make
those things available.
Kemal Armada, please.

Hello, thank you so much. I was just going to ask
about, like, what do you

think about the future of EU in
the aftermath of this disease?

I don't think there
has been enough, or like a consolidated
effort, or at least not a satisfactory one.

We see more and
more-- like, countries are confiscating each
other's supplies. And we just had Brexit.

Do you think this can
be the thing that's going to break the EU?

Yeah, crises are
never good times to test global, or regional,
or transnational solidarity.

And so I don't
find it surprising that we don't have significant
amount of regional,

or global solidarity. I think the problem with
the EU is the failure

to build up the kind of fiscal,
political, transnational institutions to back up
its economic integration.

So I think sometime
in the 1980s, the EU went whole hog in the
direction of the single market,

and economic integration, and
culminating in single money, but not a parallel
institution building

on the side of fiscal and
political institutions. And that's the fundamental
problem of the EU,

is that it is essentially
an economic union that lacks the fiscal institutions,
the common fiscal institutions,

and correspondingly the
political legitimacy of running

a unified, single market. And so it appears to most
as a kind of technocracy.

So you have all the
rules that you-- sort of the Acquis
communautaire, all the rules you need to
run a single market.

But those rules feel distant
from ordinary people.

And of course, that's
why you got Brexit. So I think to put
it very starkly, I think the choice that
the EU faces is either it's

going to have more political
integration to support the economic integration
that's already built.

Or one way or
another, we'll end up having less economic
integration, with a much sort of a
thinner economic integration

to match the thinner political
community that that's been built.

And I think the fundamental
cause of the crisis of the EU, which periodically shows
up when there are demands

on these common
institutions, on the people, is this imbalance between how
far economic integration has

gone and how weak
political integration is. And on this, you make a decision
as to whether these two will

meet at an extreme point, or
at a relatively limited point. I think the EU is always
going to get caught up
in this no man's land. Bill Ding, please.

Thank you, professor. I have a quick question. I read your book, "The
Paradox of Globalization." And in the book, you talk about
the customizable globalization,

and not all the countries
can achieve everything at the same time. So I'm just
wondering, how do you

see that going to play in the
future in the area of supply chain, because now, all
governments want to diversify

their supply chain-- looking from the US government,
from the Japanese government, from all the governments
around the world.

Thank you. Thank you. I think one way or another, I
mean, we're moving into a world

where I think these
countries will be doing more of their own thing.

So it's inevitable. And I think one thing that
happens when more countries do

their own thing is you
get some that get it right and some that get it wrong.

You know, we look at China as
a country that benefited hugely from this hyperglobalization,
but it's precisely

because China gave itself the
freedom to do its own thing. China essentially played
by the Bretton Woods rules

to its own policies. It applied all the
Bretton Woods rules

in terms of managing
its currency, controlling capital
flows, deploying

extensive industrial policies,
while essentially it's free road on the openness
policies of other countries.

And that's how China did it. So we're now going
to move into a world where I don't think it's
going to be as hospitable.

I think supply chains
really were not driving economic growth in a
lot of countries, recently--

last couple of decades. And I don't think they will be
the main driver going forward. I think countries
will have to focus

much more on the
domestic economy and on building
